questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department one hour after sustaining an injury during football practice. He collided head-on into another player while wearing a mouthguard and helmet. Immediately after the collision, he was confused but able to use appropriate words. He opened his eyes spontaneously and followed commands. There was no loss of consciousness. He also had a headache with dizziness and nausea. Upon arrival, he is no longer confused. He feels well. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is fully alert and oriented. His speech is organized and he is able to perform tasks demonstrating full attention, memory, and balance. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the crown of his head but no signs of skin break or fracture. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Admit to intensive care for intracranial pressure monitoring
Obtain MRI of the brain
Discharge without activity restrictions
Administer prophylactic levetiracetam and observe for 24 hours
Administer prophylactic phenytoin and observe for 24 hours
Discharge and refrain from all physical activity for one week
Observe for 6 hours in the ED and refrain from contact sports for one week

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Admission to the intensive care unit for intracranial pressure monitoring would be appropriate in patients with severe TBI, for which elevated intracranial pressure is a serious concern due to brain edema and/or bleeding. Severe TBI is characterized by a GCS ≤ 8. However, this patient has a GCS of 14 in the field and a GCS of 15 in the emergency department, indicating mild TBI.

B) INCORRECT:

Imaging is not an essential element in diagnosing concussion; it is largely a clinical diagnosis. Imaging would be important, however, in evaluating for intracranial bleeding or skull/facial fracture. This patient has a low likelihood for structural pathology, such as hematoma (epidural or subdural), hemorrhage, or fracture due to the normal physical and mental status examinations. Imaging would provide little benefit and is not the best next step.

C) INCORRECT:

Discharge without activity restrictions is inappropriate and against current guidelines. In this scenario, the patient may return to play that same day. Several studies exist showing that return to play without activity restrictions increases the odds of delayed symptom onset and protracted neuropsychiatric consequences.

D) INCORRECT:

Levetiracetam is a first-line agent for seizure prophylaxis after severe TBI, which manifests with a GCS ≤ 8. This patient has a GCS of 14 in the field and a GCS of 15 in the emergency department, indicating mild TBI. Seizure prophylaxis is thus not appropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenytoin is a first-line agent for seizure prophylaxis after severe TBI, which manifests with a GCS ≤ 8. This patient has a GCS of 14 in the field and a GCS of 15 in the emergency department, indicating mild TBI. Seizure prophylaxis is thus not appropriate at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Immediate discharge following mild TBI is inappropriate because patients may develop delayed-onset complications, such as intracranial bleeding. Serial clinical examinations are important for detecting such complications (as evidenced by altered mental status or focal neurological findings). Moreover, refraining from all physical activity is more strict than what is currently recommended. A gradual return to play is thought to be important in recovery from concussion.

G) CORRECT:

Observation followed by a gradual return to playing sports is the current recommendation for mild TBI. Observation in the emergency department (ED) for at least 4–6 hours should include serial neurological examination and assessment of GCS. Alterations in mental status or focal neurological signs may indicate more serious underlying pathology, such as intracranial bleeding. Following discharge, this patient should be monitored by a responsible individual for at least 24 hours after injury and return to the ED if there are any neurological changes. Patients should also progress through six stages of a gradual return to sports. As each stage requires at least 24 hours, this patient will need to refrain from contact sports for at least one week.

Neuroimaging is not routinely recommended for mild TBI. If at any point during the observation period the GCS deteriorates to < 13, patients should be reclassified as having moderate TBI or severe TBI and managed accordingly.
questions.hint: Transient headache, dizziness, nausea, and confusion at the time of head injury as well as a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) ≥ 13 at least 30 minutes after the injury is consistent with mild traumatic brain injury (TBI).

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician with his fiancée because of a 3-week history of occasional headaches and difficulty sleeping. His fiancée says that he has been unusually nitpicky and that he has also reported some difficulty concentrating at work in the past 3 weeks. One month ago, he was brought to the emergency department by his friend after hitting his head after jumping off a wall. According to his friend, he did not lose consciousness. Physical examination at that time revealed no focal neurological deficits, and his laboratory studies were consistent with alcohol intoxication but were otherwise unremarkable. A CT scan of the head was performed and showed no abnormalities. He received oral analgesics and was discharged home. He is now concerned that he might have “after-effects of the hit.” His father was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer and his sister has epilepsy. He does not smoke. He drinks six to seven alcoholic beverages every weekend and uses cannabis occasionally. He appears fatigued. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Confront the patient about the veracity of his symptoms
Schedule an elective electroencephalography
Reassure the patient and prescribe symptomatic therapy
Perform neuropsychological testing
Refer the patient to a neurologist

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While malingering should be considered in patients reporting vague, nonspecific symptoms that do not match clinical and testing findings, this patient's symptoms started shortly after an mTBI and should, therefore, raise concern for PCS, which requires different management.

B) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography may be considered in a patient who develops seizures after a documented episode of TBI. Although this patient has a history of mTBI, he has had no seizures and his presentation is consistent with PCS, which does not require electroencephalography for diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Reassurance and symptomatic therapy are the most appropriate management for patients with PCS, which is one of the most common complications of mTBI. Symptoms of PCS are highly variable and may include cognitive (e.g., difficulty concentrating, poor memory), psychiatric (e.g., irritability, affective disturbance, personality changes, apathy), and somatic changes (e.g., headaches, fatigue, sleep disturbances, dizziness). The diagnosis is clinical and is usually established based on the presence of at least three of the aforementioned symptoms after a documented TBI. Neuroimaging can be considered in patients with disabling or intractable symptoms to exclude organic causes. PCS typically resolves within 3–6 months. In patients with persistent symptoms, conservative measures such as rest and avoidance of stress, symptomatic pharmacotherapy (e.g., analgesics, antiemetics, sleeping aid), and psychotherapy can be considered. Patients and their families should also be informed on the benign nature of PCS and the possibility of a long recovery duration.

D) INCORRECT:

Neuropsychological testing is indicated for the evaluation of patients with PCS who have prominent cognitive changes (e.g., severe memory changes). Most individuals with PCS only develop minor cognitive changes (e.g., difficulty concentrating, fatigue) that subside within months, for which neuropsychological testing is not required. This patient does not have prominent cognitive changes.

E) INCORRECT:

A neurology consult is the first step in the evaluation of a patient with new-onset headaches, difficulty sleeping, irritability, and fatigue with an unknown cause. However, this patient's presentation in combination with a history of a previous mTBI makes PCS the most likely cause of his symptoms. A referral to a neurologist may be required if symptoms do not improve after 6 months.
questions.hint: A 3-week history of headaches, difficulty sleeping, difficulty concentrating, irritability, and fatigue after a mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) is consistent with postconcussion syndrome (PCS).

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male college football player is brought to the emergency department after colliding with an opponent during a football game and briefly losing consciousness. He was wearing a helmet at the time of the collision. Before this event, he was healthy and had no significant medical history. He denies any alcohol or tobacco use but reports occasional marijuana use.
He is examined 45 minutes after the head injury. He has a heart rate of 70 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 128/77 mm Hg, an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air, and a BMI of 32. His Glasgow Coma Scale score is 15. His general and neurologic examinations are normal.
Which one of the following signs or symptoms would warrant imaging of the head (CT or MRI) in this patient?

choices.text: Nausea without vomiting
Initial loss of consciousness lasting one minute
Photophobia
Dizziness when standing up from a seated position
Inability to remember events that happened 40 minutes before the collision

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vomiting after trauma is an indication for neuroimaging but nausea alone is not.

B) INCORRECT:

Brief loss of consciousness is a possible symptom of concussion but is by itself not an indication for neuroimaging after trauma. Indications for neuroimaging after trauma include a history of prolonged loss of consciousness after injury and a GCS score that declines or is persistently <15 after regaining consciousness.

C) INCORRECT:

A concussion can cause visual disturbances but photophobia per se is not an indication for neuroimaging after trauma.

D) INCORRECT:

Dizziness is a possible symptom of concussion but the mere presence of dizziness (regardless of whether it is positional or not) is not an indication for neuroimaging after trauma.

E) CORRECT:

Concussion is a clinical syndrome that develops as a result of biomechanical trauma causing rotational forces at the level of the midbrain and thalamus that can be associated with seizure activity or transient elevations in intracranial pressure. The symptoms of concussion vary in severity and can include brief confusion, brief seizure, loss of consciousness, headache, dizziness, disorientation, neck pain, anterograde and retrograde amnesia, mood changes, sleep changes, and cognitive and visual problems.

The most important diagnostic tool in concussion is a thorough physical and neurologic examination. Brain imaging via MRI or CT to assess for fractures, intracranial bleeding, or edema is recommended for a subset of patients at high risk of these complications. This subset includes patients with a Glasgow Coma Scale score persistently <15, patients taking anticoagulant or antiplatelet agents, and patients with any focal neurologic deficit. Some high-risk patients with concussion who do not meet these indications may still benefit from neuroimaging. To determine which patients are likely to benefit, standard criteria can be used, such as the Canadian CT Head Rule. According to this rule, the presence of at least one of the following criteria is considered an indication for head imaging.

High risk of neurosurgical intervention:

• Glasgow Coma Scale score <15 within 2 hours after injury
• Suspected open or depressed skull fracture
• Any sign of basilar skull fracture (hemotympanum, raccoon eyes, otorrhea/rhinorrhea, etc.)
• Two or more episodes of vomiting
• Age >65 years

Moderate risk of brain injury detected by CT:

• Retrograde amnesia for events that occurred >30 minutes before impact
• Dangerous mechanism (pedestrian struck by a motor vehicle, ejection from a motor vehicle, fall from 3 feet or more or five or more stairs)

By these criteria, the only sign or symptom listed that would provide an indication for neuroimaging in this patient is retrograde amnesia, as evidenced by an inability to remember events that occurred >30 minutes before the impact.

Key learning point: Indications for head imaging in a patient with suspected concussion include focal neurologic deficits on examination, evidence of skull fracture, a Glasgow Coma Scale score <15, and amnesia for events that occurred more than 30 minutes before the impact.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old female soccer player collides with an opposing player, falls to the ground, and hits the back of her head. She initially feels dazed and subsequently reports a headache, so she is removed from the game. Her parents bring her to the emergency department.
She denies any loss of consciousness but complains that the headache persists. She denies any vision changes, nausea, numbness, dizziness, or other symptoms. She is tearful and wants to return to play in the remaining games scheduled for that day.
Her neurologic and physical examinations are within normal limits.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe lorazepam and encourage rest
Order a CT scan of the head
Monitor her for one hour, and allow her to return to play if her headache resolves
Administer a computerized neuropsychological test
Recommend rest from sports, and adopt appropriate school accommodations

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the first 10 hours after a concussion, drugs that could alter mental status (e.g., lorazepam) should be avoided.

B) INCORRECT:

Imaging with MRI or CT is reserved for patients who have suffered head injury and develop symptoms and signs of intracerebral bleeding, such as focal neurologic deficits or deteriorating neurologic status. Formal decision aids, such as the Canadian CT Head Rule, can be used to optimize selection of patients who require neuroimaging.

C) INCORRECT:

An athlete with a concussion should not return to play the same day, even if the headache resolves. An individualized return-to-play schedule should be adopted, with a gradual increase in activity guided by symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Computerized neuropsychological testing is used for outpatient follow-up after a concussion; it is not indicated in acute or sideline management.

E) CORRECT:

Concussion, defined as a traumatically induced transient disturbance of brain function, involves a complex pathophysiological process. An athlete with a suspected concussion should be stopped from playing and assessed by a licensed health care provider who is trained in the evaluation and management of concussions.

Initial assessment of a suspected concussion should be guided by a symptom checklist, cognitive evaluation (orientation, past and immediate memory, new learning, and concentration), balance tests, and further neurologic examination. Signs and symptoms of a concussion may be physical (headache, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, fatigue), cognitive (feeling slow mentally, feeling confused about recent events, repeating questions), emotional (irritability, sadness, nervousness), and sleep related (drowsiness, difficulty falling sleep, and altered sleep duration). Athletes with a suspected or diagnosed concussion should be monitored for deteriorating physical and mental status.

Although many patients are able to return to school without problems, some experience persistent cognitive symptoms and may require learning accommodations.

Key learning point: An athlete suspected of having a concussion should not be permitted to return to play for at least the remainder of the day.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department (ED) by ambulance after falling, unhelmeted, from an all-terrain vehicle and sustaining a 45-second loss of consciousness. Emergency medical services personnel have placed her on a long board with cervical spine immobilization and report that she has been alert, with one episode of emesis.
On examination, the girl is crying and calling out for her mother. She has normal vital signs and a score of 15 on the Glasgow Coma Scale. Her breath sounds are equal bilaterally, and her peripheral pulses are strong. Her abdomen is soft and nontender. She has numerous abrasions on all four extremities but no obvious deformities. She also has a contusion on her forehead and an area of ecchymosis behind her left ear.
In addition to close monitoring, what is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain contrast CT of the head and cervical spine, and maintain cervical spine immobilization
Obtain noncontrast CT of the head and cervical spine, and maintain cervical spine immobilization
Maintain cervical spine immobilization, and observe for 2 to 4 hours in the ED with an oral challenge
Obtain noncontrast CT of the head after removing the cervical collar
Obtain MRI of the brain and cervical spine, and maintain cervical spine immobilization

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Noncontrast CT of the head is the reference standard for rapid detection of TBI and should be obtained in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

The likelihood of traumatic brain injury (TBI) in this patient is very high, given the severe mechanism of injury, loss of consciousness, postevent emesis, and discoloration behind the ear (Battle sign), which is highly suggestive of a basilar skull fracture.

Noncontrast CT of the head is the reference standard for rapid detection of TBI and should be obtained in this patient. Indications for such imaging include altered mental status, amnesia regarding the event, progressive headache, loss of consciousness, anisocoria, physical evidence of basilar skull fracture (seen in this patient), and repeated vomiting after the injury.

All children with significantly traumatic mechanisms of injury and signs of TBI (as in this case) should be assumed to have a cervical spine injury until proven otherwise. A cervical collar should remain in place to stabilize the cervical spine until injury is ruled out. Imaging options for the cervical spine include plain-film radiographs, CT, and MRI. Although CT does not provide a thorough screen for ligamentous injury, it can be used to evaluate for cervical spine fractures when adequate plain-film radiographs cannot be obtained. Plain-film radiographs, particularly open-mouth views, can be difficult to obtain in patients this young.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in care for a young child who presents to the emergency department after a traumatic fall and has physical evidence suggestive of a basilar skull fracture but an otherwise normal physical examination is to obtain noncontrast CT of the head and cervical spine and maintain cervical spine immobilization.

C) INCORRECT:

Observation for a period of 2 to 4 hours postinjury as an initial step in management is only appropriate for children who meet all of the low-risk criteria for TBI according to the PECARN (Pediatric Emergency Care Applied Research Network) guidelines. For a child ≥2 years of age, low-risk TBI criteria include normal mental status, nonsevere mechanism of injury, no loss of consciousness, no vomiting, no headache, and no evidence of basilar skull fracture. This patient has both a history of losing consciousness and evidence of basilar skull fracture on examination. Observation alone is therefore not appropriate in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

All children with significantly traumatic mechanisms of injury and signs of TBI (as in this case) should be assumed to have a cervical spine injury until proven otherwise. A cervical collar should remain in place to stabilize the cervical spine until injury is ruled out.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain may detect bleeding or skull fracture, but it is less sensitive than CT for both of these conditions in the immediate postinjury period. MRI studies are also significantly longer in duration than noncontrast CT, and in young children, MRI usually requires sedation or anesthesia. In a child with concern for TBI but a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15, avoidance of sedative medications is optimal to facilitate close monitoring of neurologic status. MRI is excellent for obtaining nuanced information about axonal injury or ligamentous cervical spine injuries. These more detailed studies are often obtained on inpatient trauma victims once initial stabilization and triage have occurred.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presents for follow-up one day after colliding head-on with another player on the football field. Yesterday, at the scene, he had no loss of consciousness, no emesis, and no weakness, but he was confused for the first 2 to 3 minutes and had difficulty answering questions about what had happened. He was taken to the emergency department, where his examination was completely normal. He was observed for 4 hours, was able to tolerate oral intake, and was discharged to home. No imaging was obtained.
Today he reports a very mild headache that worsens with rapid lateral and vertical saccades of his eyes. On physical examination, his cranial nerves are intact, his strength is 5/5 throughout, and he has normal sensation to light touch. His reflexes are 2+ bilaterally, and he has no finger-nose dysmetria. His gait is normal, but he says he feels off-balance when performing a tandem walk.
You recommend a gradual return to academics, with school accommodations put into place and then slowly removed as his symptoms improve. You note that most children’s symptoms improve within 1 to 2 weeks.
Which one of the following factors would put this patient at risk for recurrence or persistence of his symptoms?

choices.text: History of attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder
Occurrence of the concussion during a football game
Age <12 years
History of depression
Male sex

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Personal history of attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder and the type of sport being played when the concussion occurred were no different between cases and controls in this study.

B) INCORRECT:

Personal history of attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder and the type of sport being played when the concussion occurred were no different between cases and controls in this study. Other studies have shown that non-sports-related injuries may be associated with a higher risk of postconcussive symptoms than sports-related injuries.

C) INCORRECT:

Age was not a predictive factor of postconcussive syndrome in this study, although previous studies have shown that high school athletes have prolonged symptoms more often than college athletes.

D) CORRECT:

Most children recover from concussion or mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) within 1 to 2 weeks if they take a staged approach to resumption of schoolwork and sports. For example, once a child can sustain concentration for at least 30 minutes on a reading or math activity without symptoms, and once the symptoms that do develop disappear with cognitive rest, the child can reasonably progress to 1 to 3 hours of school interspersed with rest. Once he can tolerate 3 straight hours well and 4 to 5 hours with breaks, he can then progress to a full school day but should still minimize tests and homework.

Even with this staged return, some children with concussion or mild TBI may go on to develop postconcussion syndrome, which can last for months and can include a host of somatic, cognitive, sleep, and emotional disturbances. In a recent case-control study, researchers identified several characteristics that were more common among young athletes whose concussive symptoms persisted for 3 months than among those whose symptoms resolved within 3 weeks. These characteristics included a personal history of previous concussion, a personal or family history of mood disorder (such as depression), a family history of migraine, and symptom onset more than 3 hours after injury. The late onset of symptoms may be associated with a delay in care and may lead to an inappropriately early return to school and sports.

Key learning point: Postconcussion syndrome is more common in children with a history of previous concussion, a history of mood disorder (such as depression), or a family history of migraine.

E) INCORRECT:

Previous studies have suggested that females are more likely than males to experience headache, more-severe symptoms, and more-prolonged symptoms.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents for evaluation after sustaining a concussion during a football game 3 days ago. He reports headache, dizziness, nausea, and “brain fog” at today’s visit. He has not attended school this week because of his symptoms. He has otherwise been healthy and has no other significant medical history. He is eager to return to play this coming weekend because college scouts will be at his game to watch him.
What is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient’s return to play?

choices.text: Engage in strict rest until symptoms have resolved
Start with symptom-limited activity, with gradual progression to light aerobic exercise
Clear the patient for the game this weekend
Return to full-contact practice this week, and reevaluate the patient before the weekend game
Start noncontact resistance training drills at practice

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Engaging in strict rest until symptoms resolve is not recommended. Studies have shown that athletes recover more quickly and are less likely to experience prolonged symptoms when they initiate subsymptom-threshold aerobic exercise (achieving 80% to 90% of their maximum heart rate) during the first week of recovery after sports-related concussion.

B) CORRECT:

A concussion is a functional disturbance of the brain rather than a structural injury. It can be classified on an array of clinical and cognitive symptoms that may or may not include loss of consciousness. These symptoms typically follow a sequential course that can be monitored with serial neuropsychological testing.

Current guidelines recommend that patients not return to play after a concussion until they are symptom-free and have completed a graduated, stepwise return-to-sports program as in the return to play protocol.

Patients should wait at least 24 hours between each stage, such that the entire progression takes at least one week. If their symptoms return or worsen at any stage, the patient should halt their activity at that stage and return to the last stage that was completed without symptoms. The patient can reattempt progression through the stages if symptoms do not recur. In the present case, the patient is symptomatic at rest and should start at stage 1 with symptom-limited activity before gradually advancing to light aerobic exercise.

Patients should not progress beyond stage 2 until they have returned to full participation in school. Given that this patient has not returned to school, he should not start sport-specific exercises or noncontact training drills. Returning to play before symptoms resolve puts the patient at risk for further injury (both concussive and other), as concussive symptoms affect reaction times.

Key learning point: Patients who sustain a sports-related concussion should progress through a graduated, stepwise return-to-sports program and should have symptom resolution before returning to contact activities.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients should not progress beyond stage 2 until they have returned to full participation in school. Given that this patient has not returned to school, he should not start sport-specific exercises or noncontact training drills. Returning to play before symptoms resolve puts the patient at risk for further injury (both concussive and other), as concussive symptoms affect reaction times.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients should not progress beyond stage 2 until they have returned to full participation in school. Given that this patient has not returned to school, he should not start sport-specific exercises or noncontact training drills. Returning to play before symptoms resolve puts the patient at risk for further injury (both concussive and other), as concussive symptoms affect reaction times.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients should not progress beyond stage 2 until they have returned to full participation in school. Given that this patient has not returned to school, he should not start sport-specific exercises or noncontact training drills. Returning to play before symptoms resolve puts the patient at risk for further injury (both concussive and other), as concussive symptoms affect reaction times.

Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Chronic traumatic encephalopathy
Vascular dementia
Postconcussion syndrome
Normal pressure hydrocephalus
Huntington disease

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Military service carries a risk of repeated mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) from various causes such as training, falls, motor vehicle accidents, and explosive blast exposure. Repeated mTBI can cause cumulative axonal damage, blood-brain barrier disruption, oxidative stress, and chronic neuroinflammation, ultimately leading to chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE). Individuals with CTE experience early-onset, progressively worsening neuropsychological symptoms, including memory loss, personality and behavioral changes (e.g., short temper, impulsive spending), and loss of executive function (e.g., difficulty with planning tasks). Neuroimaging in CTE typically reveals nonspecific findings associated with cerebral atrophy (e.g., volume loss resulting in deepening of sulci and ex vacuo ventriculomegaly). Diagnosis is primarily clinical and can only be confirmed by postmortem evidence of hyperphosphorylated tau protein deposition in the brain.

B) INCORRECT:

Vascular dementia is a potential cause of early-onset dementia that is more common in patients with underlying cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., hypertension, hypercholesterolemia). However, vascular dementia typically has a stepwise progression and is often accompanied by focal deficits. Imaging in vascular dementia shows evidence of multiple infarctions rather than global cortical atrophy.

C) INCORRECT:

Postconcussion syndrome is the most common complication of mild traumatic brain injury and can manifest with cognitive impairment and behavioral changes but is also typically associated with other symptoms such as headaches, nausea, and light sensitivity. Moreover, postconcussion syndrome usually resolves in 6 months. This patient's symptoms have worsened progressively over a year.

D) INCORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) causes dementia and ventriculomegaly but is characterized by little to no sulcal deepening and minimal cortical atrophy. Significant cortical atrophy and sulcal deepening compared with the degree of ventriculomegaly suggest a neurodegenerative disease. Moreover, gait abnormalities and urinary incontinence are expected in NPH due to pressure on the white matter pathways of the frontal lobe and periventricular regions. Additionally, in the absence of a secondary cause (e.g., meningitis, intraventricular hemorrhage, subarachnoid hemorrhage), NPH typically occurs in individuals over 60 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Huntington disease (HD) is a cause of progressive early-onset dementia. However, the inheritance pattern of HD is autosomal dominant with genetic anticipation, and this patient does not have a parent with the disease. Additionally, HD typically manifests with motor dysfunction (classically, chorea), and neuroimaging in HD typically shows atrophy that is most pronounced in the caudate and putamen rather than global cortical atrophy.
questions.hint: Cognitive impairment (as indicated by a Montreal Cognitive Assessment score < 26) and personality changes in a patient ≤ 65 years of age suggest early-onset dementia. The most likely underlying cause in this patient is a tauopathy.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female soccer player collides with an opposing player, falls to the ground, and hits the back of her head. She initially feels dazed and subsequently reports a headache, so she is removed from the game. Her parents bring her to the emergency department. She denies any loss of consciousness but complains that the headache persists. She denies any vision changes, nausea, numbness, dizziness, or other symptoms. She is tearful and wants to return to play in the remaining games scheduled for that day. Her neurologic and physical examinations are within normal limits. What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe lorazepam and encourage rest
Order a CT scan of the head
Monitor her for one hour, and allow her to return to play if her headache resolves
Administer a computerized neuropsychological test
Recommend rest from sports, and adopt appropriate school accommodations

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the first 10 hours after a concussion, drugs that could alter mental status (e.g., lorazepam) should be avoided.

B) INCORRECT:

Imaging with MRI or CT is reserved for patients who have suffered head injury and develop symptoms and signs of intracerebral bleeding, such as focal neurologic deficits or deteriorating neurologic status. Formal decision aids, such as the Canadian CT Head Rule, can be used to optimize selection of patients who require neuroimaging.

C) INCORRECT:

An athlete with a concussion should not return to play the same day, even if the headache resolves. An individualized return-to-play schedule should be adopted, with a gradual increase in activity guided by symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Computerized neuropsychological testing is used for outpatient follow-up after a concussion; it is not indicated in acute or sideline management.

E) CORRECT:

Concussion, defined as a traumatically induced transient disturbance of brain function, involves a complex pathophysiological process. An athlete with a suspected concussion should be stopped from playing and assessed by a licensed health care provider who is trained in the evaluation and management of concussions.

Initial assessment of a suspected concussion should be guided by a symptom checklist, cognitive evaluation (orientation, past and immediate memory, new learning, and concentration), balance tests, and further neurologic examination. Signs and symptoms of a concussion may be physical (headache, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, fatigue), cognitive (feeling slow mentally, feeling confused about recent events, repeating questions), emotional (irritability, sadness, nervousness), and sleep related (drowsiness, difficulty falling sleep, and altered sleep duration). Athletes with a suspected or diagnosed concussion should be monitored for deteriorating physical and mental status.

Although many patients are able to return to school without problems, some experience persistent cognitive symptoms and may require learning accommodations.

Key learning point: An athlete suspected of having a concussion should not be permitted to return to play for at least the remainder of the day.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the office with his fiancée because of a 3-week history of occasional headaches and difficulty sleeping. His fiancée says that he has been unusually nitpicky and that he has also reported some difficulty concentrating at work in the past 3 weeks. One month ago, he was brought to the emergency department by his friend after hitting his head after falling off a roof. According to his friend, he did not lose consciousness. Physical examination at that time revealed no focal neurological deficits and brain imaging showed no abnormalities. He is now concerned that he might have “after-effects of the hit.” Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Confront the patient about the veracity of his symptoms
Schedule an elective electroencephalography
Reassure the patient and prescribe symptomatic therapy
Perform neuropsychological testing
Refer the patient to a neurologist

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While malingering should be considered in patients reporting vague, nonspecific symptoms that do not match clinical and testing findings, this patient's symptoms started shortly after an mTBI and should, therefore, raise concern for PCS, which requires different management.

B) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography may be considered in a patient who develops seizures after a documented episode of TBI. Although this patient has a history of mTBI, he has had no seizures and his presentation is consistent with PCS, which does not require electroencephalography for diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Reassurance and symptomatic therapy are the most appropriate management for patients with PCS, which is one of the most common complications of mTBI. Symptoms of PCS are highly variable and may include cognitive (e.g., difficulty concentrating, poor memory), psychiatric (e.g., irritability, affective disturbance, personality changes, apathy), and somatic changes (e.g., headaches, fatigue, sleep disturbances, dizziness). The diagnosis is clinical and is usually established based on the presence of at least three of the aforementioned symptoms after a documented TBI. Neuroimaging can be considered in patients with disabling or intractable symptoms to exclude organic causes. PCS typically resolves within 3–6 months. In patients with persistent symptoms, conservative measures such as rest and avoidance of stress, symptomatic pharmacotherapy (e.g., analgesics, antiemetics, sleeping aid), and psychotherapy can be considered. Patients and their families should also be informed on the benign nature of PCS and the possibility of a long recovery duration.

D) INCORRECT:

Neuropsychological testing is indicated for the evaluation of patients with PCS who have prominent cognitive changes (e.g., severe memory changes). Most individuals with PCS only develop minor cognitive changes (e.g., difficulty concentrating, fatigue) that subside within months, for which neuropsychological testing is not required. This patient does not have prominent cognitive changes.

E) INCORRECT:

A neurology consult is the first step in the evaluation of a patient with new-onset headaches, difficulty sleeping, irritability, and fatigue with an unknown cause. However, this patient's presentation in combination with a history of a previous mTBI makes PCS the most likely cause of his symptoms. A referral to a neurologist may be required if symptoms do not improve after 6 months.
questions.hint: A 3-week history of headaches, difficulty sleeping, difficulty concentrating, irritability, and fatigue after a mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) is consistent with postconcussion syndrome (PCS).

questions.text: A father brings his 11-month-old daughter to the emergency department one hour after he saw her fall off a bed from a height of 2 feet onto a hardwood floor. She immediately cried and never lost consciousness. After calming down, she has not vomited and is behaving normally. The child is awake and alert, and she appears well. Examination reveals a bruise on the left frontal forehead but no signs of bruising elsewhere on her body. Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain CT of the head
Observe for a few hours and discharge home
Obtain plain radiographs of the skull
Obtain a full skeletal survey
Obtain MRI of the brain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A head CT should be done first when there is concern for a skull fracture. However, a full skeletal survey should be considered if child abuse is suspected or if the circumstances of the trauma are not consistent with the known developmental abilities of the child.

B) CORRECT:

Head trauma is a common reason for emergency department visits. Neuroimaging may expose the developing brain of a child to ionizing radiation that can lead to malignancies. Prediction rules identify patients for whom imaging is unnecessary.

No imaging is necessary for children < 2 years of age who meet all of the following criteria:

• Normal mental status
• No scalp hematoma or only a hematoma in the frontal region
• No loss of consciousness or a loss of consciousness for no longer than 5 seconds
• Nonsevere mechanism of injury (e.g., a fall from < 3 feet)
• No palpable skull fracture
• Normal behavior according to the parents

A child who meets all of these criteria may simply be observed for 4 to 6 hours after the injury, followed by discharge to home with instructions about warning signs (vomiting, lethargy, or altered mental status).

Key learning point: For a patient younger than 2 years who has a bruise over the frontal skull after a recent minor head trauma but who otherwise appears well, the most appropriate next step is to observe first without imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs of the skull can confirm fractures, but they give no direct information about intracranial brain injury.

D) INCORRECT:

A full skeletal survey should be considered if child abuse is suspected or if the circumstances of the trauma are not consistent with the known developmental abilities of the child. However, even in such cases, a head CT should be done first when there is concern for a skull fracture.

E) INCORRECT:

A brain MRI can detect brain injuries but is not the preferred initial imaging study in settings of trauma. Brain MRI is not as fast as CT and typically requires sedation.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department by his father after falling off a low stool at home. He cried immediately and had no loss of consciousness or vomiting. Neurological examination shows no deficits. There are no scalp contusions or palpable bony abnormalities. He remains alert and oriented. Pupils are equal and reactive.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Urgent neurosurgical consultation
Immediate head CT scan
Skull radiographs to evaluate for occult skull fracture
Admit for close observation and repeated neurological checks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urgent neurosurgical consultation is warranted for high-risk head injuries with signs like focal deficits or altered mental status. This child has a low-impact injury, normal neurological exam, and no concerning features, indicating a low risk of significant intracranial issues.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate head CT scans are reserved for high-risk cases due to radiation risks. This child has a low-risk mechanism, normal neurological exam, and no concerning symptoms like loss of consciousness or vomiting, making significant intracranial injury unlikely. Observation is preferred to avoid unnecessary radiation exposure in the developing brain.

C) INCORRECT:

Skull radiographs are not indicated here due to the low probability of fracture. The child has a low-level fall, no loss of consciousness, and no physical signs of fracture. Advanced imaging like CT is more sensitive for fractures but is unnecessary without clinical indicators.

D) CORRECT:

In pediatric patients with minor head trauma, close observation and repeated neurological checks are crucial to monitor for delayed signs of intracranial injury. Despite a low-risk mechanism and normal initial neurological exam, children can experience delayed deterioration. Observation avoids unnecessary radiation exposure from imaging while ensuring timely detection and management of any developing intracranial issues.

Key learning point: In a child with a minor head injury, normal neurological examination, and no signs of skull fracture, close observation is the most appropriate management step to monitor for any changes in condition.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents after a motor vehicle collision in which he struck his head on the steering wheel. He denies loss of consciousness or amnesia of the event. He says he has had mild headache and 2 episodes of vomiting since the incident. Physical examination shows an occipital abrasion but no other signs of trauma. His Glasgow Coma Scale score is 15, and vital signs are normal. Neurological examination shows no focal deficits. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic step?

choices.text: MRI head without IV contrast
CT head with IV contrast
MRI head without IV contrast
No imaging required
CT head without IV contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI is not the first-line imaging modality for acute head trauma in patients meeting the Canadian CT head criteria for neuroimaging.

B) INCORRECT:

While CT head is indicated for patients meeting the Canadian CT head criteria, IV contrast is not indicated for acute head trauma evaluation as it does not improve the detection of traumatic intracranial lesions, such as hemorrhage, contusions, or fractures.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI is not the first-line imaging modality for acute head trauma in patients meeting the Canadian CT head rule criteria for neuroimaging.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's ≥ 2 episodes of vomiting fulfill the Canadian CT head rule high-risk criteria for neuroimaging.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's ≥ 2 episodes of vomiting after head trauma fulfill the Canadian CT head rule high-risk criteria for neuroimaging. CT head without IV contrast is the preferred initial imaging modality for patients meeting criteria for neuroimaging in mild traumatic brain injury, as it rapidly identifies traumatic intracranial lesions that may require neurosurgical intervention.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother after he rolled off a couch and fell approximately 4 feet onto a carpeted floor. The mother reports he cried immediately for about 5 minutes but has since been acting normally, feeding well, and has had no vomiting or seizure-like activity. On examination, the infant is alert and interactive with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 15. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is a 4-cm, non-fluctuant hematoma over the right parietal scalp. The anterior fontanelle is soft and flat. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Anteroposterior and lateral skull radiographs
Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain
Cranial ultrasound through the anterior fontanelle
Non-contrast computed tomography of the head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While skull radiographs can detect linear skull fractures, they cannot visualize the brain parenchyma to rule out intracranial hemorrhage. A patient with a documented skull fracture on X-ray would still require further evaluation, leading to additional radiation exposure and a delay in diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) provides soft-tissue detail but is not the primary imaging modality for acute head trauma. It is less sensitive than the gold standard for detecting acute hemorrhage and skull fractures. Furthermore, MRI scans are time-consuming, less readily available in an emergency setting, and typically require sedation in an infant, which carries its own risks.

C) INCORRECT:

Cranial ultrasound can be a useful, radiation-free screening tool for major intracranial hemorrhage in neonates, particularly in the neonatal intensive care setting. However, in the context of acute trauma in an infant, it has poor sensitivity for detecting skull fractures, small extra-axial fluid collections like epidural or subdural hematomas, and non-hemorrhagic parenchymal injuries.

D) CORRECT:

Non-contrast head computed tomography (CT) is the imaging modality of choice in the acute setting to rapidly and accurately evaluate for skull fractures, intracranial hemorrhage, and other traumatic brain injuries. According to the Pediatric Emergency Care Applied Research Network (PECARN) guidelines for minor head trauma in children younger than 2 years, the presence of a non-frontal scalp hematoma is a predictor of clinically important traumatic brain injury. Although this infant appears well with a GCS of 15 and no other symptoms, the parietal hematoma and fall from > 3 feet place him in an intermediate-risk category. Any intermediate-risk feature correlates with a ∼ 1% risk of clinically important TBI, which should prompt consideration for either a head CT or observation. The risk of missing a significant injury outweighs the risk of radiation exposure in this specific clinical scenario.
questions.hint: In an infant with minor head trauma, a non-frontal scalp hematoma is a predictor of an underlying skull fracture and intracranial injury, even with a normal neurologic examination.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male collegiate soccer player is brought to the emergency department after a head-to-head collision during a match 30 minutes ago. He reports a brief loss of consciousness and now reports a severe headache, nausea, and feeling "in a fog." He has no memory of the play immediately preceding the impact. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg. On physical examination, he is oriented to person and place but not time. His neurologic examination is otherwise nonfocal. Examination of the right ear shows a dark, bluish discoloration behind the tympanic membrane. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Observation for 4–6 hours with serial neurologic checks
Referral to a sports medicine concussion clinic
Non-contrast CT of the head
Administration of intravenous ondansetron and ketorolac
MRI of the brain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation with serial neurologic checks is appropriate management for a patient with a mild traumatic brain injury or concussion who has a normal neurologic examination and no signs of a more severe injury. However, this patient's hemotympanum is a significant red flag for a basilar skull fracture, which carries a risk of associated intracranial hemorrhage. Observation with serial neurologic checks could lead to a missed diagnosis of a life-threatening condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Referral to a concussion specialist is a crucial component of the long-term management and return-to-play protocol for an athlete with a concussion. However, this is not the most appropriate next step in the emergency department. The immediate priority is to rule out acute, life-threatening pathology before considering outpatient follow-up.

C) CORRECT:

A non-contrast CT of the head is the initial imaging modality of choice for evaluating acute head trauma, especially when there is concern for a skull fracture or intracranial hemorrhage. The presence of the hemotympanum elevates the concern beyond a simple concussion and mandates urgent imaging. A non-contrast CT is rapid, widely available, and highly sensitive for detecting acute hemorrhage (which appears hyperdense) and bony fractures. This allows immediate identification of life-threatening injuries such as epidural or subdural hematomas.

D) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic treatment for nausea and headache is important, but it is secondary to excluding a serious intracranial injury. Furthermore, administering ketorolac, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, is relatively contraindicated before ruling out an intracranial hemorrhage, as its antiplatelet effects could potentially worsen bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

While MRI provides superior detail of brain parenchyma and can detect subtle injuries like diffuse axonal injury, it is not the preferred initial imaging study in acute head trauma. An MRI may be considered later in the patient's course if there is a neurologic deficit unexplained by a different diagnostic approach.
questions.hint: While this patient's symptoms are consistent with a concussion, the presence of a dark bluish discoloration behind the tympanic membrane is suggestive of hemotympanum, a key sign of a basilar skull fracture.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the sideline clinic after a head-to-head collision during a soccer match. He did not lose consciousness but reports feeling “in a fog” and has a mild headache. He is oriented to person, place, and time, but cannot recall the events immediately following the impact. His vital signs are normal. On examination, his Glasgow Coma Scale score is 15. There are no focal neurologic deficits, and a cervical spine examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain a non-contrast CT scan of the head
Prescribe a short course of oral corticosteroids
Refer for immediate formal neuropsychological testing
Allow return to play if symptoms resolve within 30 minutes
Advise 24–48 hours of cognitive and physical rest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neuroimaging is considered for patients with head trauma who have red flag signs suggesting a more severe injury, such as a GCS score of less than 15, focal neurologic deficits, signs of a skull fracture, or worsening symptoms. This patient has a GCS score of 15 and a normal neurologic examination, which makes an intracranial injury unlikely and immediate imaging unnecessary.

B) INCORRECT:

There is no evidence to support the use of corticosteroids in the management of acute concussion. Although they are potent anti-inflammatory agents, their use is not part of standard concussion protocols and may be associated with adverse effects.

C) INCORRECT:

While formal neuropsychological testing can be a useful tool in managing complex or prolonged concussion symptoms, it is not indicated for immediate, acute management. Testing may be considered later if recovery is not proceeding as expected.

D) INCORRECT:

This practice is outdated and dangerous. Returning to play prematurely increases the risk of prolonged recovery and second impact syndrome, a rare but potentially catastrophic event.

E) CORRECT:

The initial management for a sports-related concussion is immediate removal from play followed by a period of relative cognitive and physical rest. This approach aims to reduce the brain's metabolic demands, which are elevated post-injury, and to prevent a second, more severe injury (second impact syndrome). Physical rest involves avoiding sports and strenuous activities, while cognitive rest involves limiting activities that require significant concentration, such as schoolwork, video games, and extensive screen time. After this initial rest period, a gradual, stepwise return-to-learn and return-to-play protocol is initiated, guided by symptom resolution.
questions.hint: This athlete's post-traumatic amnesia and feeling 'in a fog' after a head impact are hallmark signs of a concussion, even without loss of consciousness.
